revision.comment: /* Australia */Added Bryan creek crossing changed to coleraine, victoria, australia
revision.text:
This is a list of [[city|cities]] and [[town]]s whose names were officially changed at one or more points in history. It does not include gradual changes in spelling that took place over long periods of time.
''see also:'' [[Geographical renaming]] and [[Names of European cities in different languages]]. {{TOC right}}
=={{AFG}}== * [[Alexandria Ariana]] → [[Herat]] * [[Alexandria Arachosia]] → [[Kandahar]] (Refer [[Kandahar#Name]]) * [[Alexandria in Opiania]] → [[Ghazni]] * [[Alexandria on the Oxus]] → [[Al-Khanoum]] * [[Bactra]] → [[Balkh]] * Adina Pur → [[Jalalabad]]
=={{DZA}}== *Ikosium → Icosium → [[Algiers]] *Géryville → [[El Bayadh]] *Cirta → [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]] *Hippo Regius → Bône → [[Annaba]] *Rusicade → Philippeville → [[Skikda]] *Castellum Tingitanum → Orléansville → El Asnam → [[Chlef]] *Malaca → Calama → [[Guelma]] *Colomb-Béchar → [[Béchar]] *Saint André de Mers-el-Kébir → [[Mers-el-Kébir]] *[[Saldae]] → Bougie → [[Béjaïa]] *Fort Laperrine → [[Tamanrasset]]
=={{AGO}}== *[[Amboim]] → [[Cabela]] → [[Gabela]] *[[Benguella]] → [[Benguela]] (1975) *[[Cabinda (city)|Cabinda]] → [[Tchiowa]] (proposed) *Carmona → [[Uíge]] (1975) *[[Concelho]] → [[Caconda]] (1975) *[[Henrique de Carvalho]] → [[Saurimo]] (1975) *[[Huambo]] → [[Nova Lisboa]] → [[Huambo]] (1975) *Loanda → [[Luanda]] (1975) *Moçâmedes → Namibe (1985) → [[Moçâmedes]] (2016) *[[Novo Redondo]] → [[Sumbe]] (1975) *[[Kissonde]] → Benguela → [[Benguela Velha]] → [[Porto Amboim]] (1923) → [[Gunza]]/[[Porto Gabela]] (proposed) *[[Porto Alexandre]] → [[Tombwe]]/[[Tombua]] *[[Robert Williams town]]/[[Vila Robert Williams]] → [[Caála]] (1975) *Sá da Bandeira → [[Lubango]] *São Salvador → [[M'banza-Kongo]] (1975) *Santa Comba → [[Waku-Kungo]] (1975) *[[Santo António do Zaire]] → [[Soyo]] *[[Serpa Pinto]] → [[Menongue]] (1975) *Silva Porto → [[Kuito]]/[[Cuito]] (1975) *[[Teixeira da Silva]] → [[Bailundo]]/[[Bailunda]] *[[Teixeira de Sousa]] → [[Luau, Moxico|Luau]] (1975) *[[Vila Luso]] → [[Luena, Moxico Province|Luena]] (1975) *[[N'dalatando|Vila Salazar]] → [[N'dalatando]] (1975)
=={{ARG}}== *La Plata → Ciudad Eva Perón → [[La Plata]]
=={{ARM}}== ''See [[List of renamed cities in Armenia]]''
*Akhta → [[Hrazdan]] *Alagyoz → Tsakhkahovit → [[Aragats]] (1950) *Artashat → Verin Ghamarlu → [[Artashat, Armenia|Artashat]] (1962) *Basarkechar → [[Vardenis]] (1945) *Dadakishlag → Akhundov → [[Punik]] *Davalou → [[Ararat, Armenia|Ararat]] (1935) *Dyuzkand → [[Akhuryan]] (1950) *Geryusi → [[Goris]] (1924) *Hamamlou → [[Spitak]] (1948) *Jalaloghlou → [[Stepanavan]] (1930) *Ghapan → [[Kapan]] (1990) *Karaklis → Kirovakan (1935) → [[Vanadzor]] (1993) *Krasnoselsk → [[Chambarak]] (1993) *Kumayri → Alexandropol (1840) → Leninakan (1924) → [[Gyumri]] (1990) *Kyavar → Novo-Bayazet/Nor Bayazet (1830) → Kamo (1959) → [[Gavar]] (1996) *Lusavan → [[Charentsavan]] (1967) *Nerkin Karanlough → [[Martuni, Armenia|Martuni]] (1926) *Sardarapat → Hoktemberyan (1932) → [[Armavir, Armenia|Armavir]] (1992) *Soylan → Azizbekov (1956) → [[Vayk]] (1994) *Nubarashen → Sovetashen → [[Nubarashen]] *Uloukhanlou → Narimanlou → Zangibasar → Razdan → [[Masis (city)|Masis]] *Vagharshapat → [[Echmiadzin]] (1941) → Vagharshapat (1991) *Vorontsovka → Kalinino (1937) → [[Tashir]] (1991)
=={{AUS}}== {{See also|Australian place names changed from German names}} *Ballaarat → [[Ballarat]] (VIC) *Bearbrass → [[Melbourne]] (VIC) *Belfast → [[Port Fairy]] (VIC) *Bendigo's Creek → Sandhurst → [[Bendigo]] (VIC) *Blackman's Flat → [[Orange, New South Wales|Orange]] (NSW) *Bryan Creek Crossing → [[Coleraine, Victoria|Coleraine]] (VIC) *Currajong → [[Parkes, New South Wales|Parkes]] (NSW) *Dumbletown → [[Beverly Hills, New South Wales|Beverly Hills]] (NSW) *Emerald Hill → [[South Melbourne]] (VIC) *Emu Bay → [[Burnie]] (TAS) *Flooding Creek → [[Sale, Victoria|Sale]] (VIC) *Germanton → [[Holbrook, New South Wales|Holbrook]] (NSW) *Hummock Hill → [[Whyalla]] (SA) *Limestone Station → [[Ipswich, Australia|Ipswich]] (QLD) *Mayday Hills → [[Beechworth]] (NSW) *McGuire's Punt → Sheppardtown → [[Shepparton, Victoria|Shepparton]] (VIC) *Mobilong → [[Murray Bridge]] (SA) *Newcastle → [[Toodyay]] (WA) *Port Darwin → Palmerston → [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] (NT) *Stuart → [[Alice Springs]] (NT)
=={{AZE}}== ''See [[List of renamed cities in Azerbaijan]]''
*[[Mardakert (town)|Mardakert]] → Ağdərə (1991, change not recognized by the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] which controls this city) *Aşağı Ağcakənd → Şaumyanovsk (1938) → [[Aşağı Ağcakənd]] (1990) *Astraxan-Bazar → [[Jalilabad|Cəlilabad]] (1967) *Beyləqan → Zhdanov (1939) → [[Beylagan|Beyləqan]] (1991) *Biləsuvar → Puşkino (1938) → [[Bilasuvar|Biləsuvar]] (1991) *Dəvəçi → Şabran (2010) *Duvannı → [[Sanqaçal]] *Gəncə → Elisabethpol (1805) → Gəncə (1918) → Kirovabad (1935) → [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Gəncə]] (1989) *Goranboy → Qasım-İsmayılov (1938) → [[Goranboy (city)|Goranboy]] (1990) *Helenendorf → Yelenino → Xanlar (1938) → [[Goygol (city)|Göygöl]] (2008) *Karyagino → [[Füzuli]] (1959) *Xonaşen → [[Martuni (town)|Martuni]] → Xocavənd (1991, change not recognized by the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] which controls this city) *Noraşen → İliç[evsk] → [[Sharur|Şərur]] (1991) *Petropavlovka → Petropavlovsk → [[Sabirabad (city)|Sabirabad]] (1931) *Port-Ilich → [[Liman, Azerbaijan|Liman]] (1999) *Prishib → [[Göytəpə, Jalilabad|Göytəpə]] *Qutqaşen → [[Qəbələ]] (1991) *Şəki → Nuxa (1840) → [[Shaki, Azerbaijan|Şəki]] (1968) *Şəmkir → Şamxor → [[Şəmkir]] (1991) *Tərtər → Mir-Bəşir (1949) → [[Tərtər]] (1991) *Traubenfeld → Vinogradnoe Pole → [[Tovuz, Azerbaijan|Tovuz]] *Vartaşen → [[Oghuz (city)|Oğuz]] (1991) *Xankəndi → [[Stepanakert]] (1923) → Xankəndi (1991, change not recognized by the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]] which controls this city) *Yelizavetinka → Lüksemburq → [[Agstafa|Ağstafa]] (1939) *Yeni Şamaxı → [[Agsu (city)|Ağsu]] *Zubovka → [[Ali Bayramli|Əli-Bayramlı]] (1938) → [[Shirvan (city)|Şirvan]] (2008) *Pirçivan → [[Zəngilan]] (1957)
=={{BAN}}== {{see also|List of renamed places in Bangladesh}} *[[Jahangir Nagar]] → [[Dacca]] → [[Dhaka]] *[[Chittagong]] → [[Chattogram]] *[[Barisal]] → [[Barishal]] *[[Jessore]] → [[Jashore]] *[[Comilla]] → [[Cumilla]] *[[Bogra]] → [[Bogura]]
=={{BLR}}== ''See [[List of renamed cities in Belarus]]''
*Berestie (Берестье) (historical ruthenian name) → Brześć Litewski (polish name) → Brest-Litovsk (Брест-Литовск) (Russian name since 19th century as transcribed from Polish*) → Brest (Брест) (*) → Brest (Брэст)/Bierascie (Берасце) (informal)
=={{BEL}}== * [[Charnoy]] (hamlet) → [[Charleroi]] (1666)
=={{BOT}}== * Gaberones → [[Gaborone]] (1969)
=={{BIH}}== * Bosanska Dubica → [[Kozarska Dubica, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Kozarska Dubica]] (1992) * Bosanska Gradiška → [[Gradiška, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Gradiška]] * Bosanska Kostajnica → [[Kostajnica, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Kostajnica]] * Bosanski Brod → [[Brod, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Brod]] * Bosanski Novi → [[Novi Grad, Republika Srpska|Novi Grad]] * Bosanski Šamac → [[Šamac, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Šamac]] * Bosansko Petrovo Selo → [[Petrovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Petrovo]] * Delminium → Županjac → Županj-potok → Županjac → Duvno → Tomislavgrad → Duvno → [[Tomislavgrad]] * [[Drvar]] → Titov Drvar (1981) → Drvar (1991) * Hvoča → Foča → Srbinje → [[Foča]] * Skender Vakuf → [[Kneževo, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Kneževo]]

=={{COD}}== {{main|Former place names in the Democratic Republic of the Congo}} A number of places became towns/cities under a Belgian colonial name, or rather two: in Dutch (often ending in -stad) and French (often ending in -ville, also meaning 'town') (the Belgian official languages), but were later renamed in native languages, such as :
* [[Albertstad]] = [[Albertville]] (colonial) → [[Kalemie]] * [[Boudewijnstad]] = [[Baudouinville]] (colonial) → [[Kirungu]] * [[Coquilhatstad]] = [[Coquihatville]] (colonial) → [[Mbandaka]] * [[Costermansstad]] = [[Costermansville]] (colonial) → [[Bukavu]] * [[Elisabethstad]] = [[Elisabethville]] (colonial) → [[Lubumbashi]] * [[Jadotstad]] = [[Jadotville]] (colonial) → [[Likasi]] * [[Leopoldstad]] = [[Léopoldville]] (colonial) → [[Kinshasa]] * [[Luluabourg (city)|Luluaburg/ Luluabourg]] (colonial) → [[Kananga]] * [[Bangala Station]] → [[Nieuw-Antwerpen]] = [[Nouvelle-Anvers]] (colonial) → [[Makanza]] * [[Ponthierstad]]/[[Ponthierville]] (colonial) → [[Ubundu]] * [[Port Franqui]] → [[Ilebo]] * [[Stanleystad]] = Stanleyville (colonial) → [[Kisangani]]

=={{ZAF}}== :''This section of the article can be expanded with material from the [[:af:Pleknaamsveranderinge in Suid-Afrika|corresponding page]] in Afrikaans Wikipedia - '''but there 'voorgestel' means the name change is merely proposed, not executed'' {{main|Renaming in South Africa}} Although many name changes have taken place officially since 1994, the previous names are still common in use, especially by the white communities (* means that all or some road signs still print the former name). This list doesn't include unofficially or proposed name changes such as [[Pretoria]] to Tshwane.

{{pp|small=yes}} {{multiple issues| {{cleanup-list|date=October 2015}} {{famous|date=October 2015}} }} <!-- * Only add names if the individuals have their _own articles_, establishing notability. * Anything else will be removed. --> Here is a '''list of notable [[Hacker (term)|hacker]]s''' who are known for their hacking acts.
{{Compact ToC | short1 | num=yes | sym=no | seealso=yes | notesfirst=no | further=no | extlinks=no}}
==0–9== <!-- * Only add names if the individuals have their _own articles_, establishing notability. * Anything else will be removed. --> {{empty section|section=1|date=September 2015}}
==A== <!-- * Only add names if the individuals have their _own articles_, establishing notability. * Anything else will be removed. --> * [[Mark Abene]] (Phiber Optik)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gabriel|first1=Trip|title=Reprogramming a Convicted Hacker; To His On-Line Friends, Phiber Optik Is a Virtual Hero|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/14/nyregion/reprogramming-convicted-hacker-his-line-friends-phiber-optik-virtual-hero.html|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=17 March 2015|date=14 January 1995}}</ref> * [[Ryan Ackroyd]] (Kayla)<ref name=lulz>{{cite web|last1=Bright|first1=Peter|title="The cutting edge of cybercrime"—Lulzsec hackers get up to 32 months in jail|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/05/the-cutting-edge-of-cybercrime-lulzsec-hackers-get-up-to-32-months-in-jail/|publisher=[[Ars Technica]]|accessdate=17 March 2015|date=16 May 2013}}</ref> * [[Mustafa Al-Bassam]] (Tflow)<ref name=lulz/> * [[Mitch Altman]]<ref name=bridge>{{cite web|last1=Tweney|first1=Dylan|title=DIY Freaks Flock to ‘Hacker Spaces’ * [[Jacob Appelbaum]] (ioerror)<ref name=rolling>{{cite web|last1=Rich|first1=Nathaniel|authorlink1=Nathaniel Rich (novelist)|title=The American Wikileaks Hacker|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/meet-the-american-hacker-behind-wikileaks-20101201|publisher=''[[Rolling Stone]]''|accessdate=21 March 2015|date=1 December 2010}}</ref> * [[Julian page.title: List of people with breast cancer

revision.comment: Rescuing 4 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
<!--- Please follow contribution guidelines on the discussion page when contributing to this list. ---> [[File:GretaGarbo1920s.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Actress [[Greta Garbo]] was a [[breast cancer]] patient]]
This '''list of notable people with breast cancer''' includes people who made significant contributions to their chosen field and who were diagnosed with [[breast cancer]] at some point in their lives, as confirmed by public information. Diagnosis dates are listed where the information is known.
According to the [[United States]] [[National Cancer Institute]], an estimated 192,370 new cases and 40,170 deaths (women only) would occur in the United States in 2009.<ref>[http://www.nci.nih.gov/cancertopics/pdq/treatment/breast/HealthProfessional/page2 General Information About Breast Cancer], National Cancer Institute; retrieved October 2, 2009.</ref>
==Acting== {| class=wikitable |- ! style="width:17%;"| Name ! style="width:14%;"| Life ! style="width:46%;"| Comments ! style="width:15%;"| Diagnosis ! style="width:8%;"| Reference |- valign="top" | | '''[[Christina Applegate]]''' | (1971 – present) | American Emmy-winning actress | diagnosed in 2008 at age 36 | |- valign="top" | '''[[Dame Eileen Atkins]]''' | (1934 – present) | British actress | diagnosed in 1995 at age 61 | [https://archive.is/20130125194516/http://www.hollywood.com/celebs/fulldetail/id/199060] |- valign="top" | '''[[Daniel Baldwin|Carol Martineau Baldwin]]''' | (19?? - present) | Mother of American actors [[Alec Baldwin]], [[Daniel Baldwin|Daniel]], [[Stephen Baldwin|Stephen]], and [[William Baldwin|William]]; founder of the Carol M. Baldwin Breast Care Center of the University Hospital and Medical Center at Stony Brook | diagnosed in 1990 | [http://www.uhmc.sunysb.edu/surgery/carol.html] |- valign="top" | '''[[Kaye Ballard]]''' | (1925 – present) | American actress | diagnosed in 1994 at age 68 | [http://www.classictvhits.com/cast.php?id=3676] |- valign="top" | '''[[Allyce Beasley]]''' | (1954 – present) | American actress | diagnosed in 1998 at 44 | [http://people.com/archive/over-the-moon-vol-53-no-7] |- valign="top" | '''[[Rita Tushingham|Aisha Bicknell]]''' | (1971 – present) | Daughter of British actress [[Rita Tushingham]] | diagnosed in April, 2005 at age 33 | [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/health/2006/08/21/hknack21.xml] |- valign="top" | '''[[Shirley Temple|Shirley Temple Black]]''' | (1926 – 2014) | American child star and U.S. Ambassador to [[Ghana]] and [[Czechoslovakia]]; died at 85 of [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] | diagnosed in 1972 at age 46 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20070216014826/http://healingribbons.com/Merchant5/merchant.mvc?Screen=stories_famous_faces] |- valign="top" | '''[[Yasmine Bleeth|Carina Bleeth]]''' | (1942 – 1989) | Mother of American actress [[Yasmine Bleeth]]; died of [[inflammatory breast cancer]] at age 47 | diagnosed in 1988 at age 46 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20050825094317/http://www.ibcmemorial.org/carina.html] |- valign="top" | '''[[Diahann Carroll]]''' | (1935 – present) | American Oscar-nominated actress and singer | diagnosed in 1998 at age 63 | [https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/spotlight/2001-07-23-carroll-mammograms.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Bette Davis]]''' | (1908–1989) | American Oscar-winning actress; died at age 81 | diagnosed in 1983 at age 75 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20080723014931/http://www.bettedavis.com/about/bio.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Ruby Dee]]''' | (1922–2014) | American Oscar-nominated actress; died in 2014 from natural causes | diagnosed in the 1970s | [http://marriage.about.com/od/entertainmen1/p/davisdee.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Diana Dill|Diana Douglas]]''' | (1923–2015) | British-American actress; first wife of American actor [[Kirk Douglas]] and mother of American actor [[Michael Douglas]] | diagnosed in mid-1990s; died of an undisclosed form of cancer in 2015, aged 92 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928083656/http://uttm.com/stories/2003/04/23/earlyshow/leisure/celebspot/main550754.shtml] |- valign="top" |- valign="top" | '''[[Jill Eikenberry]]''' | (1947–present) | American actress | diagnosed in 1986 at age 39 | [http://www.medindia.net/Patients/PatientInfo/breastcancer_celebrities.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Belinda Emmett]]''' | (1974–2006) | Australian actress; had a recurrence in 2001; died November 11, 2006 at age 32 | diagnosed in 1998 at age 24 | <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pr-inside.com/australian-soap-star-emmett-loses-cancer-battle-r25557.htm|title=NEWS AUSTRALIAN SOAP STAR EMMETT LOSES CANCER BATTLE|publisher=Pr-inside.com|accessdate=2010-07-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928161251/http://www.pr-inside.com/australian-soap-star-emmett-loses-cancer-battle-r25557.htm|archivedate=2011-09-28}}</ref> |- valign="top" | '''[[Edie Falco]]''' | (1963–present) | American actress | diagnosed in 2003 at age 40 | [http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/08/05/1091557967607.html?from=storyrhs] |- valign="top" | '''[[Kay Francis]]''' | (1905–1968) | American actress; died at age 63 | diagnosed in 1966 at age 61 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20060613002911/http://divasthesite.com/Acting_Divas/Trivia/Trivia_Kay_Francis.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Maria Friedman]]''' | (1960–present) | British actress | diagnosed in 2005 at age 45 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20060211052924/http://newsfromrussia.com/usa/2005/11/14/67570.html] |- valign="top" | '''[[Helen Gahagan]]''' | (1900–1980) | American actress and politician; wife of actor [[Melvyn Douglas]]; died at age 80 | diagnosed in 1972 at age 72; recurred in 1976 | [http://www.geoghegan.org/clan/helengahagandouglas/] |- valign="top" | '''[[Greta Garbo]]''' | (1905–1990) | Swedish-American Oscar-nominated actress; survived breast cancer following a double mastectomy; cause of death was kidney and stomach failure and pneumonia; died in 1990 at age 84 | diagnosed in 1984 at age 79 | [https://web.archive.org/web/19991202034758/http://home.hiwaay.net/~oliver/timeline5.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Paulette Goddard]]''' | (1910–1990) | American Oscar-nominated actress; survived breast cancer, but died at age 79 following a brief battle with [[emphysema]] | diagnosed in 1975 at age 65 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20071020171709/http://www.tvave.com/AcademyAwards-P/Paulette_Goddard.php] |- valign="top" |'''[[Florence Halop]]''' | (1923–1986) | American actress; died at age 54 | diagnosed in 1984 at age 48 | [https://web.archive.org/web/20080403185142/http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_story/793:0/1/Jill_Ireland.htm] |- valign="top" | '''[[Kate Jackson]]''' | (1948–present) | American actress; page.title: List of rail transport modelling scale standards

revision.comment: cat
revision.text:
{{see also|Rail transport modelling scales}} This page lists the most relevant '''model railway scale standards''' in the world. Most standards are regional, but some have followers in other parts of the world outside their native region, most notably [[Normen Europäischer Modelleisenbahnen|NEM]] and [[NMRA]]. While the most significant standardised dimension of a model railway scale is the gauge, a typical scale standard covers many more aspects of model railways and defines scale-specific dimensions for items like [[Overhead lines|catenary]], [[Wheelset (rail transport)|rolling stock wheels]], [[loading gauge]], [[Minimum railway curve radius|curve radii]] and [[Grade (slope)|grades for slopes]], for instance. == Scale standards == === NEM === [[MOROP]] (the European federation of national model railway associations) is a European organisation which publishes [[Normen Europäischer Modelleisenbahnen|NEM]]-standards. NEM-standards are used by model railway industry and hobbyists in Europe. The standards are published in French and German and both versions have an official status. Unofficial translations in English from third parties exist for certain NEM-standard sheets. Model railway scales and gauges are standardized in NEM 010,{{cite web|url=http://www.miba.de/morop/nem010_d.pdf|publisher=[[MOROP]]|title=Normen Europäischer Modellbahnen Maßstäbe, Nenngrößen, Spurweiten | language=German|date=2011|accessdate=2014-05-15}} which covers several gauges for each scale. Narrow gauges are indicated by an additional letter added after the base scale as follows: * no letter = [[standard gauge]] (prototype: {{convert|1250|-|1700|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}}) * m = [[metre gauge]] (prototype: {{convert|850|-|1250|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}}) * e = [[Narrow gauge railway|narrow gauge]] (prototype: {{convert|650|-|850|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}}) * i = [[Industrial railway|industrial]] (prototype: {{convert|400|-|650|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}}) * p = [[List of ridable miniature railways|park railway]] (prototype: {{convert|300|-|400|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}}) For instance, a metre gauge model railway in H0-scale would be designated H0m. In German text letter 'f' (stands for Feldbahn) is sometimes used instead of 'i'. Letter 'e' is derived from the French word 'étroit' which translates to 'narrow'. NEM gauges are arranged conveniently to use normal gauge of smaller scales as narrow gauges for a certain scale. For instance, H0m gauge is the same as the TT scale normal gauge, H0e same as the N scale normal gauge and H0i same as the Z scale normal gauge For H0 and 0 -scales, NEM uses the number zero or the letter 'O', whereas NMRA uses letter 'O' (HO instead of H0). Regardless of whether a letter or number is used, the scale is the same. {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Standard gauge !! m !! e !! i !! p !! Notes |- | [[Z scale|Z]] || 1:220 || {{RailGauge|6.5 mm}} || 4.5 mm || – || – || – || Based on [[Märklin]] factory standards. |- | [[N scale|N]] || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} || 6.5 mm || 4.5 mm || – || – || Based on [[Arnold (models)|Arnold]] factory standards. |- | [[TT scale|TT]] || 1:120 || {{RailGauge|12 mm}} || 9 mm || 6.5 mm || 4.5 mm || – || – |- | [[HO scale|H0]] || 1:87 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || [[H0m gauge|12 mm]] || [[H0e gauge|9 mm]] || [[H0f gauge|6.5 mm]] || 4.5 mm || "Half O" |- | [[S scale|S]] || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|22.5 mm}} || 16.5 mm || 12 mm || 9 mm || 6.5 mm || – |- | [[O scale|0]] || 1:45 || {{RailGauge|32 mm}} || 22.5 mm || 16.5 mm || 12 mm || 9 mm ||   |- | [[1 gauge|1]] || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|45 mm}} || 32 mm || 22.5 mm || 16.5 mm || 12 mm || – |- | [[2 gauge|II]] || 1:22.5 || {{RailGauge|64 mm}} || 45 mm || 32 mm || 22.5 mm || 16.5 mm ||Known as Gauge 3 in the UK; |- | [[3 gauge|III]] || 1:16 || {{RailGauge|89 mm}} || 63.5 mm || 45 mm || 32 mm || 22.5 mm || – |- | [[V scale (railroad modeling)|V]] || 1:11 || {{RailGauge|5in|first=imp}} || 89 mm || 63.5 mm || 45 mm || 32 mm || – |- | [[VII scale|VII]] || 1:8 || {{Track gauge|7.25in|first=met}} || 127 mm || 89 mm || 63.5 mm || 45 mm || – |- | [[X scale|X]] || 1:5.5 || {{RailGauge|10.25in|first=met}} || 184 mm || 127 mm || 89 mm || 63.5 mm || – |} === NMRA === The [[NMRA]] (National Model Railroad Association) standardized the first model railway scales in the 1940s. NMRA standards are used widely in North America and by certain special interest groups all over the world. To some extent NMRA and NEM standards are compatible, but in many areas, the two standards specify certain model railway details in somewhat incompatible ways for the same scale. There are two NMRA standard sheets where the scales have been defined. NMRA standard S-1.2 covers the ''popular model railway scales'' and S-1.3 defines ''scales with deep flanges'' for model railways with very sharp curves or other garden railway specific design features. In certain NMRA scales an alternative designation is sometimes used corresponding the length of one prototype foot in scale either in millimetres or in inches. For instance, 3.5 mm scale is the same as HO. For [[HO scale|HO]] and [[O scale|O]] -scales, NMRA uses the letter 'O' whereas NEM uses the number zero (H0 instead of HO). NMRA has defined alternative, more prototypical, track and wheel system standards in standard sheet S-1.1 for the purposes of reproducing the prototype proportions in scale model more realistically. These model railway standards are based on the full size prototype standards and the scale model operational reliability is therefore reduced in comparison to the models conforming to the normal NMRA standards. Proto and finescale rails and wheels are generally not compatible with the normal scale model railway material with the same scale ratio. Proto scale was originally developed by the Model Railway Study Group in Great Britain in 1966 and later adopted into NMRA standards with modifications necessary for the North American prototype railway standards. Proto scale reproduces faithfully the prototype wheel tread profile and track work used by the [[Association of American Railroads]] and the [[American Railway Engineering Association]]. Finescale reproduces the prototype wheel tread profile and track work used by the Association of American Railroads and the American Railway Engineering Association with minor compromises for performance and manufacturability. ==== NMRA popular railway scales ==== {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Model gauge !! Notes |- | [[Z scale|Z]] || 1:220 || {{RailGauge|0.256in|first=met}} || NMRA does not give any other dimensions for Z-scale apart from the gauge
The s.g. is set nominally to gauge=6.5 mm; more exact to 1:220 would be 6.52 mm (0.257 in) |- | [[Nn2 scale|Nn2]] || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|0.177in}}
{{RailGauge|4.5 mm}} || narrow gauge |- | [[Nn3 scale|Nn3]] || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|0.256in}}
{{RailGauge|6.5 mm}} || narrow gauge |- | [[N scale|N]] || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|0.353in}} || standard gauge |- | [[TT scale|TT]] || 1:120 || {{RailGauge|0.47in}}
{{RailGauge|0.472in}}
{{RailGauge|12 mm}} || standard gauge |- | [[HOn2 scale|HOn2 or 3.5 mm]] || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|7 mm}} || narrow gauge |- | [[HOn30 gauge|HOn30 or 3.5 mm]] || 1.87.1 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} (0.353 in.) || narrow gauge--N scale track can be used |- | [[3 ft gauge rail modelling|HOn3 or 3.5 mm]] || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|10.5 mm}} || narrow gauge |- | [[H0m gauge|HOm or 3.5 mm]] || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|12 mm}} || narrow gauge--TT scale track can be used |- | [[HO scale|HO or 3.5 mm]] || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|0.65in}} || standard gauge |- | [[00 gauge|OO or 4 mm]] || 1:76.2 || {{RailGauge|0.75in}} || standard gauge |- | [[Sn3 scale|Sn3 or 3/16″]] || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|0.563in}} || narrow gauge |- | [[S scale|S or 3/16″]] || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|0.883in}} || standard gauge |- | [[On2 scale|On2 or 1/4″]] || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|12.7 mm}} || narrow gauge |- | [[On30|On30 or 1/4″]] || 1:48 || HO-track || narrow gauge |- | [[On3 scale|On3 or 1/4″]] || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|0.75in}}
{{RailGauge|19.4 mm}} (?) || narrow gauge |- | [[O scale|O or 1/4″]] || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|1.25in}} || 1.177 in (28.9 mm) is true standard gauge |- | [[1n3 scale|No. 1n3 or 3/8″]] || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|1.125in}} || narrow gauge |- | [[1 scale|No. 1 or 3/8″]] || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|1.766in}} || standard gauge |- | [[Fn3 scale|Fn3 or 15 mm]] || 1:20.32 || No. 1-track || narrow gauge |- | [[15 mm scale|F or 15 mm]] || 1:20.32 || {{RailGauge|2.781in}} || Identical to Proto 20.32 except the wheel flange depth |- | [[3/4" scale|3/4″]] || 1:16 || {{RailGauge|3.5in}} || standard gauge |- | [[1" scale|1″]] || 1:12 || {{RailGauge|4.75in}} || – |} Note: to interpret the number in the left hand column, these examples illustrate: * 3.5 mm scale (HO): 3.5 mm scale measurement = 1 foot (304.8 mm) prototype. The ratio is therefore 1:87.08571, usually reported as 1:87. * 1" scale: 1" scale measurement = 1 foot prototype, the ratio is reported as 1:12. ==== NMRA deep flange scales ==== {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | SHR or 3/16″ || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|0.865in}}
vs. {{convert|0.865|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} || – |- | O27 || – || – || Same as OHR but models 10% smaller
on the same track gauge |- | OHR or 1/4″ || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|1.25in}} || – |- | G or 3/8″ || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |- | G || 1:29 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |- | G || 1:24 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |- | G || 1:22.5 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |- | G || 1:20.3 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |} ==== NMRA proto scales ==== {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | Proto:20.32 || 1:20.32 || {{RailGauge|70.64 mm}} || NMRA[http://www.nmra.org/sites/default/files/standards/sandrp/pdf/S-3.1%202006.01.pdf NMRA 70.64mm][http://www.nmra.org/sites/default/files/standards/sandrp/pdf/s-3.2_2010.05.08.pdf NMRA 70.69mm] |- | Proto:20.32n3 || 1:20.32 || {{RailGauge|1.772in}} || – |- | Proto:32 || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|1.766in}} || – |- | Proto:32n3 || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|1.125in}} || – |- | Proto:48w5 || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|1.25in}} || Russian prototypes |- | Proto:48 || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|1.177in}} || – |- | Proto:48n3 || 1:48 || {{RailGauge|0.75in}} || – |- | Proto:64 || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|0.883in}} || – |- | Proto:64n3 || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|0.563in}} || – |- | Proto:87 || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|0.65in}} || – |- | Proto:87n3 || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|0.413in}} || – |} ==== NMRA finescale ==== {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | Fine:HO || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|0.65in}} || – |- | Fine:HOn3 || 1:87.1 || {{RailGauge|0.413in}} || – |- | Fine:TT || 1:120 || {{RailGauge|0.47in}}
{{RailGauge|0.472in}} || – |-| Fine:TTn3 || 1:120 || {{RailGauge|0.353in}} || – |- | Fine:N || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|0.353in}} || – |- | Fine:Nn3 || 1:160 || {{RailGauge|0.25in}} || – |} === British === The main railways in Great Britain use the international [[standard gauge]] of {{RailGauge|uksg}} but the [[loading gauge]] is narrower and lower than in the rest of Europe with the same standard gauge. This is one of the main reasons why the country has traditionally used its own distinctive model railway scales which can rarely be found outside the British Isles. When H0 scale was being introduced, the motors available were too largehttp://www.hobbiesplus.com.au/scaleandgauge.htm to fit in scale-sized bodies and so as a compromise the scale was increased from 3.5 mm to 4 mm to the foot, but the gauge was not changed so other elements could be shared. For 00 therefore the track is narrower than it should be for the scale used. EM and P4 standards correct this anomaly by adopting a wider track gauge. The globally more-widespread international NEM and NMRA scale standards are relatively rare in Great Britain and used almost exclusively by those modelling foreign prototypes. {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | 000 or 2 mm || 1:152 || {{RailGauge|9.42 mm}} || An early predecessor of small scales like N. Developed before [[World War II]] and became somewhat popular in the 1950s. No commercial products available. Today The 2mm Scale Association is the force behind the scale and 2 mm scale has become a finescale alternative to the British N-scale. |- | [[N gauge|N]] || 1:148 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} || A British adaptation of N-scale for modelling British prototypes with a smaller loading gauge. Has a track gauge error of approximately -7%. Hobbyists who model European or American prototypes in Britain, use the standard N-scale with the scale ratio 1:160. |- | [[TT scale#British TT|TT/TT3]] or 3 mm || 1:102 || {{RailGauge|12 mm}} || Introduced by Triang in 1957 as a British adaptation of the American TT scale. Later Triang dropped this scale in favour of N scale and today there is no commercial following. Has a track gauge error of approximately -15% (the rolling stock superstructures are too large for its gauge). Those models can drive on straight and curved sections of German BTTB Standard Gleis except crossings and switches. |- | [[H0 gauge|H0]] or 3.5 mm || 1:87 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || H0 scale was introduced in Britain in the 1920s, and although it stayed as the most common worldwide modelling scale, in Britain H0 has little commercial availability and is generally only used to model the British prototype by a small number of modellers. |- | [[00 gauge|00]] or 4 mm || 1:76 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || The most popular railway modelling scale in Britain. The correct track gauge at the scale of 4 mm per foot should be approximately 18.8 mm. At 16.5 mm, it has a track gauge error of approximately -12.4%. |- | [[EM gauge|EM]] or 4 mm || 1:76 || {{RailGauge|18.2 mm}} || This gauge is represented by the EM Society (in full, Eighteen Millimetre Society). 00 track (16.5 mm) is the wrong gauge for 1:76 scale, but use of an {{RailGauge|18.2 mm}} gauge track is accepted as the most popular compromise towards scale dimensions without having to make significant modifications to ready-to-run models. Has a track gauge error of approximately -3.5%. |- | [[Protofour|P4]]/S4 or 4 mm || 1:76.2 || {{RailGauge|18.83 mm}} || Uses a track gauge of 18.83 mm which represents an exact scaling down of the prototype at 4 mm to 1 ft scale. P4 contains an allowance for the tighter curves found on model railways in the wheel back-to-back and related dimensions. S4 removes this allowance, for a dead-scale representation of all trackwork dimensions. Both standards are now maintained by the Scalefour Society and are now applied to other prototypical track gauges (such as Irish broad gauge). |- | [[O14]] || 1:43.5 || {{RailGauge|14 mm}} || For accurately representing 2 ft narrow gauge in 7 mm scale. |- | [[O scale|0]] or 7 mm || 1:43.5 || {{RailGauge|32 mm}} || Three sub-standards: coarse, unified and fine. Has a track gauge error of approximately -3%. |- | [[ScaleSeven]] (S7) 7 mm || 1:43.5 || {{RailGauge|33 mm}} || A finescale represented by The ScaleSeven group. |} === Japanese === While there are Japanese model railway manufacturers that export their products to other parts of the world and follow the scale standards of the export destinations, in Japan there are several domestic scales that are popular in the country but virtually unknown elsewhere. International NEM and NMRA scales are also used by some Japanese modellers. The main reason for the domestic scales different from international standards is the smaller prototype loading gauge and unusual gauges of Japanese railways: {{RailGauge|600mm}}, {{RailGauge|762 mm}} and {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} are used, along with standard gauge of {{RailGauge|1435 mm}}. {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | [[T scale|T]] || 1:450
1:480 || {{RailGauge|3 mm}} || Launched at 2006 Tokyo Toy Show by Eishindo Co. |- | [[ZZ scale|ZZ]] || 1:300 || {{RailGauge|4.8 mm}} || Introduced 2005 by [[Bandai]] |- | [[Z scale|Z]] or ZJ || 1:220 || {{RailGauge|6.5 mm}} ||   |- | [[N scale|N]] || 1:150
1:160 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} || The most popular scale in Japan. For models of [[Shinkansen]] high speed trains and other systems
using standard gauge track, the international N scale standard ratio of 1:160 is commonly used. |- | TT9 || 1:120 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} || Used also in New Zealand. |- | HOn2½ || 1:80 || {{RailGauge|9 mm}} || Used for {{RailGauge|2ft6in}} narrow gauge. |- | 13 mm || 1:80 || {{RailGauge|13 mm}} || Correct for {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} Japanese narrow gauge. |- | HOj or #16 || 1:80 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || Used for ready-to-run models of {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} prototypes. |- | HO || 1:87 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || Used for models of [[Shinkansen]] high speed trains and other systems using standard gauge track. |- | HOn3-1/2 || 1:87 || {{RailGauge|12 mm}} || Correct for {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} Japanese narrow gauge. |- | [[Sn3½]] || 1:64 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || Used for ready-to-run models. |- | - || 1:50 || {{RailGauge|20.5 mm}} || Static models mostly. |- | OJ || 1:45 || {{RailGauge|24 mm}} || Correct for {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} Japanese narrow gauge. |- | [[O scale|O]] || 1:45
(1:40-1:42) || {{RailGauge|32 mm}} || 1:40-1:42 used about 1930s. |- | 35 mm || 1:30 || {{RailGauge|35 mm}} || Used for {{RailGauge|1067 mm}} Japanese narrow gauge. |- | [[1 gauge|# I or 45 mm]] || 1:30 || {{RailGauge|45 mm}} ||   |} === Live steam === [[Live steam]] model railways are not standardized systematically by any single standardization body. There are, however, certain scales and gauges which have become de facto standards and in some cases correspond to either NEM or NMRA standard scales. One example is the "IBLS" ([http://www.ibls.org International Brotherhood of Live Steamers]), an informal organization which has published standards for some of the gauges. Many clubs have their own standards, which also may vary slightly from country to country. [[Hornby Railways]] have pioneered commercial model live steam in 00 (1:76 scale on 16.5 mm gauge), the existing models are heated using a controllable electric current through the two running rails and have the steam pressure chamber in the model tender. In addition to these scales, the United Kingdom has, over the last forty years, fathered a scale that is based on the predominant British narrow track gauge of {{RailGauge|2ft}}. Using {{RailGauge|32 mm}} - 0 gauge - track, there is an extensive range of 16 mm to the foot scale [1:19] live-steam and other types of locomotives, rolling stock and accessories. Many of these models are dual gauge, and can be converted to run on {{RailGauge|45 mm}} track ([[gauge 1]]), and radio control is common. Locomotives in this scale are generally large and 'chunky', and can range from the tiny 0-4-0 seen on Welsh slate quarry lines all the way up to the very largest found in the UK, such as the ex-ACR NG/G16 Beyer-Garratt locomotives, seen running on the Welsh Highland Railway in North Wales. The hobby is supported by a number of 16 mm live steam and electric traction builders, dominated by the likes of Roundhouse Engineering and Accucraft UK. {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Standard gauge !! Notes |- | [[00 gauge|00]] || 1:76 || {{RailGauge|16.5 mm}} || Hornby produced. Generally regarded as the smallest scale for live steam. Discontinued in 2011 due to poor sales and reliability of the units. The operating instructions from Hornby were incorrect and led to many locomotives being broken after derailing and crashing to the floor. There is still much interest and lively sales of secondhand sets. The 00 Live Steam Club also promotes the product. |- | [[O scale|O]] || 1:45 || {{RailGauge|32 mm}} || Popularly used for the small scale live steam. |- | No.1 || 1:32 || {{RailGauge|45 mm}} || Popularly used for the small scale live steam. Corresponds to NEM 1 or NMRA No. 1. |- | No.3 || 1:22.6 || {{RailGauge|64 mm}} || The smallest scale able to pull real passengers. Was one of the first popular live steam gauges, developed in England in the early 1900s. In terms of model railway operation, gauge 3 is the largest (standard gauge) scenic railway modelling scale, using a scale of 13.5 mm to the foot. The Gauge '3' Society represents this aspect of 2{{fraction|1|2}}" gauge railway modelling with both electric and live steam operation. Gauge '3' corresponds to NEM II scale, also known as 'Spur II' in Germany. The National 2.5″ Association continues to support live steam passenger hauling in 2.5″ gauge using MES tracks. They use a 'scale' appropriate to the original prototype modelling both standard and narrow gauge locomotives to run on 2.5″ track. |- | - || 1:16 || {{RailGauge|3.5in}} || A worldwide garden railroad scale. Corresponds to NEM III and NMRA 3/4″. |- | - || 1:12 || {{RailGauge|4.75in}} || North America specific scale corresponding to NMRA 1″ scale. 1:12 is one of the most popular backyard railway scales. |- | - || 1:11 || {{RailGauge|5in}} || Used outside North America. Corresponds to NEM V. One of the most popular [[garden railway]] scales. |- | - || 1:8 || {{RailGauge|7.25in}} || Used in North-Eastern US, Canada, Europe and other parts of the world. Corresponds to NEM VII. |- | - || 1:8 || {{RailGauge|7.5in}} || Used in the Western parts of the US. |- | - || 1:7.5 || || 1.6in=1 ft. Used in the US, often finer-scale. Uses 7.5in gauge. |- |} === Static model === {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | 41 mm || 1:35 || 41 mm (1.614 in) || 41 mm is used by several static model manufacturers, often for models of military subjects such as [railway guns]http://www.etamiya.com/shop/trumpeter-00207-280mm-leopold-german-railroad-p-90014292.html as 1:35 is a popular scale for rail modelling. 41 mm was introduced in the 2000s.[http://www.cmkkits.com/en/ CMK][http://www.dragon-models.com/ Dragon-models] [http://www.trumpeter-china.com/ Trumpeter] |} === Historical === There have been many short-lived and often promising model railway scales which are very much defunct nowadays. Quite often these were backed by only the company that created a new scale in the first place. {| class=wikitable |- ! Scale !! Ratio !! Gauge !! Notes |- | K || 1:180 || {{RailGauge|8 mm}} || Introduced 1948 at the Hannover Fair in Germany by Walter M. ''K''ersting. |- | [[N scale#OOO models|OOO]] || – || {{RailGauge|22 mm}} || Introduced in 1902 by Schoenner in Germany. |- | OO || – || {{RailGauge|23 mm}} || Introduced in 1908 by Märklin and sold under name "Liliput-Eisenbahn" until 1932. |- | Z0 || 1:60 || {{RailGauge|24 mm}} || Z0 or "Zwischen Null" (between 0) was in use in the 1940s and 1950s by several model railway manufacturers in Germany. Standardized in East German NORMAT model railway standard collection. Z0 was originally introduced in [[Czechoslovakia]] in 1938. |- | 35 mm || 1:30 || {{RailGauge|35 mm}} || 35 mm was in use in the 1930s and 1940s by several model railway manufacturers in Japan. 35 mm was introduced in the 1930s. Late 1940s 35 mm was replaced by [[O scale|O gauge]]. |- | No. 2 || 1:27 || {{RailGauge|2 in}} || English scale, {{frac|7|16}} inch to 1 foot. Commercially used about 1900{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} |} == See also == * [[National Model Railroad Association]] * [[Normen Europäischer Modelleisenbahnen]] * [[Rail transport modelling scales]] * [[Rail transport modelling]] * [[List of narrow gauge model railway scales]] == External links == * [http://www.lionel.com/ForTheHobbyist/Guides/AboutGuage.cfm "About Gauge" guide] from Lionel discussing O versus O27 gauge * [http://www.lionel.com/ForTheHobbyist/Guides/MoreAboutGuage.cfm "More About Gauge" guide] from Lionel discussing gauges other than O == References == {{Commons category|Model railway scales}} {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List of rail transport modelling scale standards}} [[Category:Rail transport modelling standards]] [[Category:Model railroad scales|*]] [[Category:Scale model scales| ]] [[Category:Lists of standards|Rail transport modelling scale standards]] [[Category:Lists of track gauges|Modelling scale standards]]

page.title: List of the Mesozoic life of Arizona

revision.comment: Removed duplicate entries per instructions by [[User:Abyssal]] on my talk page.
revision.text:
This '''list of the Mesozoic life of Arizona''' contains the various prehistoric life-forms whose [[fossil]]ized remains have been reported from [[Paleontology in Arizona|within]] the US state of [[Arizona]] and are between 252.17 and 66 million years of age.
==A== [[File:Douvilleiceratidae - Acanthohoplites hannoverensis.JPG|thumb|upright|Fossilized shell of the Early Cretaceous ammonoid cephalopod ''[[Acanthohoplites]]'']]<!-- [[Acanthohoplites]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Acrodus nobilis Exhibit Museum of Natural History.JPG|thumb|right|[[Acrodus]]]] --><!-- [[Acrodus]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Acteon tornatilis 2.png|thumb|right|[[Acteon (gastropod)]]]] --><!-- [[Acteon (gastropod)]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Adocidae - Adocus punctatus.jpg|thumb|right|[[Adocus]]]] --><!-- [[Adocus]]: Automatic taxobox --> [[File:Glyptops and Adocus.jpg |thumb|upright|Illustration of the fossilized shell and skull of ''[[Glyptops]]'' (left and center) and the shell of ''[[Adocus]]'']]<!-- [[Adocus]]: lead section --> [[File:Allocrioceras pariense.jpg|thumb|upright|Fossilized shell of the Late Cretaceous ammonoid cephalopod ''[[Allocrioceras]]'']]<!-- [[Allocrioceras]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Angistorhinus.JPG|thumb|right|[[Angistorhinus]]]] --><!-- [[Angistorhinus]]: Automatic taxobox --> [[File:Angistorhinus grandis.jpg|upright|thumb|Life restoration of the Late Triassic phytosaur ''[[Angistorhinus]]'']]<!-- [[Angistorhinus]]: lead section --> <!-- [[File:Anomia ephippium.jpg|thumb|right|[[Anomia (genus)]]]] --><!-- [[Anomia (genus)]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Louisae.jpg|thumb|right|[[Apatosaurus]]]] --><!-- [[Apatosaurus]]: Automatic taxobox --> [[File:Apatosaurus louisae by durbed.jpg|upright|thumb|Life restoration of the Late Jurassic sauropod dinosaur ''[[Apatosaurus]]'']]<!-- [[Apatosaurus]] --> [[File:Araucarioxylon arizonicum (petrified wood) - National Museum of Natural History, United States - DSC08540.JPG|thumb|right|Petrified trunk segments of the Permian-Late Triassic conifer tree ''[[Araucarioxylon arizonicum]]''. This species is the [[state fossil]] of Arizona]] <!-- [[File:Arca zebra.jpg|thumb|right|[[Arca (bivalve)]]]] --><!-- [[Arca (bivalve)]]: Taxobox --> [[File:Chinle fish.jpg|thumb|upright|Life restorations of various Chinle Formation fishes, including the Late Triassic lungfish ''[[Arganodus]]'' (bottom)]]<!-- [[Arganodus]]: Taxobox --> [[File:Ctenosauriscid model.jpg|thumb|upright|Restorative model of the Middle Triassic primitive crocodile relative ''[[Arizonasaurus]]'']]<!-- [[Arizonasaurus]]: Automatic taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Arizonasaurus BW.jpg|right|thumb|Restoration]] --><!-- [[Arizonasaurus]] --> [[File:Australosomus merlei.JPG|thumb|upright|Fossil slab and counterslab of the Early Triassic bony fish ''[[Australosomus]]'']]<!-- Charonia appenninica.JPG|thumb|240px|right|Fossil shell of ''Charonia appenninica'' from Pliocene of Italy]] --><!-- [[Charonia]] --> [[File:Chindesaurus bryansmalli.png|thumb|upright|Life restoration of the Late Triassic theropod dinosaur ''[[Chindesaurus]]'']]<!-- [[Chindesaurus]]: Speciesbox --> <!-- [[File:Chindesaurus scale.png|thumb|right|Comparison of the size of ''Chindesaurus'' and a human]] --><!-- [[Chindesaurus]] --> <!-- [[File:Chindesaurus.jpeg|thumb|right|Restoration from [[Petrified Forest National Park]]]] --><!-- [[Chindesaurus]] --> [[File:Chinlea BW.jpg|thumb|upright|Life restoration of the Late Triassic coelacanth fish ''[[Chinlea]]'']]<!-- [[Chinlea]]: Taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Cheirotherium prints possibly Ticinosuchus.JPG|thumb|right|[[Chirotherium]]]] --><!-- [[Chirotherium]]: Ichnobox/short --> <!-- [[File:Fossil track of a Chirotherium. Triassic Period. From England. Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, Glasgow, UK.jpg|thumb|right|Fossil track of a Chirotherium. Triassic Period. From England. Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, Glasgow, UK]] --><!-- [[Chirotherium]] --> [[Image:Chirotherium.jpg|thumb|upright|Restorative model of the hypothetical trackmaker of the Late Triassic ichnogenus ''[[Chirotherium]]'' with real fossil footprints in the background]]<!-- [[Chirotherium]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis bauri mount.jpg|thumb|right|[[Coelophysis]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]]: Automatic taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis size.jpg|thumb|right|Size of ''C. bauri'' compared to a human]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis-bauri head.jpg|thumb|right|''C. bauri'' profile]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis bauri.jpg|right|thumb|Two Ghost Ranch specimens preserved together, AMNH]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis mount NHM2.jpg|thumb|right|Cast of the neotype specimen AMNH FR 7224, [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]], London]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis rhodesiensis.JPG|thumb|right|Profile of the head of ''Coelophysis rhodesiensis'']] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis with crocodylomorph bones AMNH.jpg|thumb|right|Bones in a skeleton of ''C. bauri'' at the [[American Museum of Natural History]], now interpreted as those of a [[crocodylomorph]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis skeletons.jpg|right|thumb|Two ''C. bauri'' casts mounted at the [[Denver Museum of Nature and Science]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis block.jpg|right|thumb|Specimen block, [[New Mexico History Museum|New Mexico Museum]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:CMNH Coelophysis Block.jpg|right|thumbnail|The [[Cleveland Museum of Natural History|Cleveland Museum of Natural History's]] ''Coelophysis'' block, originally [[American Museum of Natural History]] block XII collected by [[Edwin H. Colbert|Colbert]] in 1948.<ref name="rinehart_etal_2009"/>]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:Coelophysis Jeff Martz.jpg|right|thumb|Restoration showing hypothetical [[Wattle (anatomy)|wattle]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> <!-- [[File:PSM V66 D145 Carnivorous dinosaur tracks in high relief preserved in stone.png|thumb|right|''Grallator'' from [[Middletown, Connecticut]]]] --><!-- [[Coelophysis]] --> [[File:SyntarsusDB.jpg|thumb|upright|Life restoration of ''[[Coelophysis kayentakatae]]'']]<!-- [[Coelophysis kayentakatae]]: Speciesbox --> [[File:Gasteropods - Ammonites - Collignoniceras woolgari.JPG|thumb|upright|Fossilized shell of the Late Cretaceous ammonoid ''[[Collignoniceras]]'']]<!-- [[Collignoniceras]]: Automatic taxobox --> <!-- [[File:Corbula modesta
